so that that that toolkit approach is pretty important we also have a group of
customers that tell us they're adopting an API program because they're trying to re-engineer their existing organization

vocabulary or the dictionary of terms everyone who works in an API program

actually have to design this part of the system as well and the good news is most organizations have something like this

regulated businesses like health and insurance in banking have published
standardized shared committee models on terms like this in objects and titles

a is a description in a machine readable form of all the properties and actions
all the arguments and return values so what's a it's like the blueprint element
but it doesn't have anything to do with a protocol or a format so it doesn't say
you're gonna use HTTP it doesn't say you're gonna use WebSockets it doesn't say you're gonna use HTML or collection
JSON or uber it doesn't say any of those things those things are implementation details that's building materials that
will be decided on site when they get the blueprints but this profile is a sort of technology agnostic machine
readable description that other people can use we've seen variations on how this is implemented there are a few
formalized document formats or languages for this that we'll talk about I've even
seen people just simply have their own internal confluence document or wiki page or something that's done in a
really standardized kind of way but the idea is to document all the metadata all the properties and all the
actions in a way that developers will be able to understand and then finally you can develop in as design API reference
API reference documentation often looks like it has some implementation details
in it it'll have things like this is a this is a an HTTP POST or this is a PUD
or this is a gat or this is a query string so generating one of those early
on is very helpful to two developers most organizations start with that API reference however that API reference is

this is where we apply CSS where we make sure that all our user interfaces look

that we have latitude longitude ID city name address all those terms and they're
all the actions query by city save record remove record
all these phrases all these action elements that's the vocabulary so you

to click on the wrong thing or hard for them to fill the wrong value into a field and that's what applying
vocabularies does and essentially what we want to do is normalize the words we
use on the interface so that it matches the words everyone else in the organization or everyone else in the

are lots of open vocabularies of a group called schema.org has a fantastic open
vocabulary this was started by Microsoft Yahoo Google and eventually Yandex from
Russia so they're all search engine people and they wanted people to mark up all of their search results using the
